content: Given an arbitrary square matrix with the row sum of each row fixed. Could anyone explain or hint how to rigorous establish that a matrix with pairwisely perpendicular rows (properly ordered) is an optimal solution to the determinant optimization problem?

It might be related to the Birkhoff-Von Neumann problem? If the determinant is convex in any useful way (not sure convexity even makes sense), then you know it's maximized on doubly stochastic matrices (which what you asked for, unless you're allowed negative coefficients?) by an extreme point, which is a permutation matrix thanks to Birkhoff-Von Neumann.

This seems like a reasonable way to formally prove the result, but I feel it can be tedious to encode it.

This seems like a job for Lagrange multipliers and Jacobi's formula. A sketch:

First, consider the submanifold of k×kk\times kk×k matrices where row iii has length cic_ici​, with c1,…,ck>0c_1,\dots,c_k>0c1​,…,ck​>0. This submanifold is a level set of A↦(∥v1∥,…,∥vk∥)A\mapsto (\lVert v_1\rVert,\dots,\lVert v_k\rVert)A↦(∥v1​∥,…,∥vk​∥) for the codomain point (c1,…,ck)(c_1,\dots,c_k)(c1​,…,ck​), and let AAA denote a matrix in this submanifold. Let AiA_iAi​ denote the matrix AAA, but setting all but row iii to 000. The matrices A1,…,AkA_1,\dots,A_kA1​,…,Ak​ span the subspace of the tangent bundle that are orthogonal to the submanifold at AAA.

One version of Jacobi's formula is that ∂det⁡(A)/∂Aij=adj⁡(A)ji\partial\det(A)/\partial{A_{ij}} = \operatorname{adj}(A)_{ji}∂det(A)/∂Aij​=adj(A)ji​, where AijA_{ij}Aij​ is entry (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) of AAA. A critical point of det⁡\detdet when restricted to the submanifold corresponds to a matrix AAA where the matrix (∂det⁡(A)/∂Aij)ij(\partial\det(A)/\partial{A_{ij}})_{ij}(∂det(A)/∂Aij​)ij​ lies in the subspace spanned by A1,…,AkA_1,\dots,A_kA1​,…,Ak​, thus we can say each column of adj⁡(A)\operatorname{adj}(A)adj(A) is a scalar multiple of the corresponding row of AAA.

Assuming det⁡(A)≠0\det(A)\neq 0det(A)=0, then AAA is invertible, so adj⁡(A)=det⁡(A)A−1\operatorname{adj}(A)=\det(A)A^{-1}adj(A)=det(A)A−1. Since AA−1=IAA^{-1}=IAA−1=I, putting this all together the rows of AAA are pairwise perpendicular. We can ignore det⁡(A)=0\det(A)=0det(A)=0 as an optimum since the diagonal matrix with c1,…,cnc_1,\dots,c_nc1​,…,cn​ on the diagonal gives a lower bound for the maximal determinant.

You can rephrase my argument above to make it more direct: if AAA is a square matrix, then you should be able to show that there exists a unitary matrix UUU such that AUAUAU is upper triangular. This has the same (absolute value of) determinant as AAA, and the norms of the rows are the same. But now the conclusion is clear, since the determinant is a product of diagonal entries, and the norms are lower bounded by diagonal entries.
I think this is called Hadamard's inequality and searching that should give a proof.

Hadamard matrices are ones for which Hadamard inequality turns into equation (one can renormalise the nxn matrix to have its rows and columns to be of squared Euclidean norm n, and entries have norm at most 1 (and thus exactly 1).
